column7: General Information
column9: Initiative from the undisclosed GRI (found by the coder but not mentioned in the GRI index table)

column7: IGO Limited is an ASX 100 listed Company focused on creating a better planet for future generations by discovering, developing and delivering products critical to clean energy. We are a purpose-led organisation with strong, embedded values and a caring culture for our people and stakeholders. We are Making a Difference by safely, sustainably and ethically delivering the products our customers need to advance the global transition to decarbonisation.

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: The Sustainability Report covers activities currently under exploration and discovery, projects in development, managed operations and joint ventures for IGO and its subsidiary companies. All performance data relates to IGO-managed operations only unless otherwise stated.

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: IGO's ninth Sustainability Report presents our sustainability performance from 1 July 2022 to 30 June 2023 (FY23).
There was no restatement of any information.
BDO assurance practitioner reports on limited assurance engagement relating to sustainability reporting.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: Through our upstream mining and downstream processing assets, IGO enables future-facing technologies, including the electrification of transport, energy storage and renewable energy generation. IGO's nickel business includes the Nova and Forrestania Operations and the Cosmos Project, all located in Western Australia.\t

An essential part of FY23 was growing our business and welcoming over 300 new people and their families to IGO. Over the last 12 months, we have delivered many work programs to ensure that our new employees feel included and safe and that they share in the benefits we offer our people.\t
Total temporary employees consist of 36% female and 64% male\t

Stakeholders, Board: Audit & Risk Committee Nomination & Governance Committee; People, Performance & Culture Committee; Sustainability Committee, Managing Director and CEO, Executive Leadership Team\t

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column7: Unless otherwise noted, the following persons held office as Directors of IGO during the whole financial year and up to the date of this report: Debra Bakker, Samanta Hogg, Michael Nossal, Justin Osborne, Keith Spence, and Xiaoping Yang.\t

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: The Board.\t

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column13: Our sustainability framework is built on seven pillars centred around our purpose, Making a Difference. We recognise sustainability and commercial issues are often connected and part of a constantly evolving system. These pillars form the structure of our sustainability management, reporting, target, and measurements of progress, with the report structured to address each sustainability pillar.
column20: Climate change, risk assessment, strategic planning\t

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column7: Our Board is supported by the Sustainability Committee, Audit and Risk Committee, Nomination and Governance Committee and People, Performance and Culture Committee. Each Committee works within a Charter approved by the Board, which sets out the roles and responsibilities, composition structure and membership requirements.\t

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column7: Sustainability Committee to maintain effective good governance and accountability concerning its performance and approach to our material sustainability-related risks in safety and well-being, climate change and decarbonisation, Traditional Owners, environment, ethics, heritage and land access, and community.\t

To manage conflicts of interest, individuals must disclose any actual, potential or perceived conflict to their manager. Where applicable, if the conflict cannot be effectively managed or resolved, they may need to disclose it to the Company Secretary.\t

column13: All people listed in this section can receive disclosures that qualify for protection under the Australian whistleblower laws. However, we encourage you to disclose to our Speak Up Protection Officers or "Your Call", an independent and confidential external reporting service.
column20: Investment decisions, net zero emissions, AET1.5 scenario\t

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column7: The Board regularly evaluates its membership to ensure it has the suitable combination of skills, qualities, knowledge, experience and capabilities to fulfil the current and future needs of the Company. Following the Nomination & Governance Committee Charter and the Company's Diversity, Inclusion and Equal Employment Opportunity Standard, the Board seeks members with demonstrable skills, qualities, capability, and experience with the ability to challenge existing practices and processes to ensure their relevancy and function as a cohesive team.\t

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column13: By IGO's practice of continuously seeking ways to improve our processes, this year, IGO engaged a third party, Board Outlook, to assist with the Board evaluation process, which included the completion of a comprehensive online survey and a workshop to examine the results. Through this new process, a range of feedback on the performance of the Board and its Committees was received, including how the Board interacts with the management team and broader organisation.
column20: Board evaluation, continuous improvement, feedback mechanism

column7: The remuneration policy is transparent, with information communicated to all employees to create a high level of understanding of the link between pay, performance, culture, behaviours and delivery against Company objectives and values.

column13: The Committee undertakes a broad review of data derived from remuneration consultants who track industry levels to ensure it is fully informed when making remuneration decisions. During the year ended 30 June 2023, no remuneration recommendations, as defined by the Corporations Act 2001, were provided by remuneration consultants.
column20: Industry Data-driven Decision-making, Comprehensive Remuneration Review, Compliance with Corporate Legislation

column7: The ratio of the annual total compensation for the organisation's highest-paid individual to the median annual total compensation for all employees is 9.13\t

column13: Recorded the first sales of battery-grade lithium hydroxide produced from the Kwinana Refinery in Western Australia to customers in the battery supply chain. Progressed our downstream nickel strategy with land allocation at Kwinana for a proposed Integrated Battery Material Facility (IBMF) producing precursor cathode active material (PCAM). Progressed discussions with global battery PCAM manufacturers to partner in the project
column20: Lithium Hydroxide Sales, Downstream Nickel Strategy, Battery Material Facility Progress

column13: IGO actively promotes ethical and responsible decision-making by clearly stating our values and purpose in our Code of Conduct. Our purpose and values guide what we do and how we do it. A system of internal controls supports our Code of Conduct, risk management process, corporate governance framework, and healthy corporate culture, which has been implemented to drive continuous improvement and promote responsible conduct.
column20: Renewable energy, energy efficiency, climate change policy\t

column7: In addition to maintaining our commitment to responsible conduct, we also seek to align our values with those we do business with and will adopt a Supplier Code of Conduct during FY24. We hold a high standard for protecting the security of all personal information handled, including information belonging to our employees, contractors, suppliers and other stakeholders. During the year, a new privacy standard was adopted to ensure IGO meets its regulatory obligations under the Privacy Act and best practices.\t

Code of Conduct, Anti-bribery and Corruption Standard, Continuous Disclosure and Information Standard, Dealing in Securities Standard, Diversity and Equal Opportunity Standard, Privacy Standard, Speak Up Standard, and Conflict of Interest Standard.\t

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column7: IGO's Speak Up Program provides various means for anyone to report concerns. In FY23, one report on exploration field activities was made through the Speak Up Program. It has been investigated and is being addressed.
In FY23, one report on exploration field activities was made through the Speak Up Program. It has been investigated and is being addressed.\t

We combined feedback from IGO employees, leaders, and subject matter experts (internal), considered stakeholder expectations, community feedback, and investor surveys, and analysed the external environmental and prevalent issues given media attention (external).
Employees are subject to collective bargaining agreements.
